item.content:encoded:
In this blog post I will describe the proof of concept code sharing going on in the common mobile client shared library (Portable Class Library).

Creating the common library

The basis of this blog post is Paul Batum's excellent tutorial on GitHub. I am not going to regurgitate what he has, but I will add a few things.

  • You do not need to download the mobile services sample from Azure.
    • Create a PCL project in Xamarin Studio (or Visual Studio), ensure that it is a PCL project, not a regular C# (or F#) library.
    • Add the Nuget package Microsoft.Net.Http
    • Follow the rest of the steps in the tutorial
  • Originally I had an older PCL project before I started to refactor my code to share the Azure Mobile Services client logic. After following the instructions I was getting compile errors complaining that it could not find the IDisposable interface in version 4.0 of the .Net framework. This was a bug that has since been fixed, however, it looks like the bug was to do with the csproj, not VS/Xamarin Studio, so either create a new project like I did, or if that is not feasible, look at project file in the tutorial and do a diff.
  • I didn't need to follow the WP8 instructions. I just needed to add the appropriate Nuget packages.
  • I will go through this in the iOS tutorial, but you for that platform you need to call CurrentPlatform.Init()

The code

public interface IDataClient  
{
    Task< IEnumerable <InternetLocation >> GetLocations( double latitude,  double longitude);
}

public class DataClient : IDataClient  
{
    private readonly MobileServiceClient _client = newMobileServiceClient ("https://yourmobileservice.azure-mobile.net/" ,"xxKEYxx" );

    public Task< IEnumerable <InternetLocation >> GetLocations( double latitude, double longitude)
    {
        return _client.GetTable< InternetLocation >().WithParameters(
                            new Dictionary <string , string >
                           {
                                  { "longitude" , longitude.ToString(CultureInfo .InvariantCulture)},
                                  { "latitude" , latitude.ToString(CultureInfo .InvariantCulture)}
                           }).ToEnumerableAsync();
    }
}

Obviously replace the URL and key with your own. The code here is pretty straight forward. If you go back to my TableController blog post it will call the GetLocationsNear method on the InternetLocationController using the passed in longitude and latitude.

Wait, shouldn't there be more common code?

At this point you may be wondering why there isn't more code sharing going on. In terms of illustrating code sharing this proof of concept may have been a poor choice, as I will illustrate in future blog posts the mapping functionality by its nature (and the nature of the platforms) is very view specific which is where you need to craft platform specific code.

MvvmCross and Xamarin.Mobile allow you to use a common location component. While for my proof of concept I did not go down this route, it is certainly available to you.

Hopefully though, even with this small example, you will start to see the power of what Xamarin offers.

Update: Xamarin just announced Xamarin.Forms which has a maps control. Looking at the sample code, however, at the moment it only supports pins. You will need to install the Nuget package (Xamarin.Forms.Maps) to get the maps installed. At present the sample doesn't support Android due to a Google Maps API key dependency. The sample can be found here.

item.title: Creating an Apple Maps custom overlay image with Xamarin
item.description:
Want to add an Apple Maps image overlay with Xamarin? Heres how!

When working on my proof of concept one especially large pain point was figuring out how to add a correctly scaled image overlay to my maps in order to display the represented WiFi signal range. In this blog
item.dc:creator: Stephen Kennedy
item.content:encoded:
Want to add an Apple Maps image overlay with Xamarin? Heres how!

When working on my proof of concept one especially large pain point was figuring out how to add a correctly scaled image overlay to my maps in order to display the represented WiFi signal range. In this blog post I will take you through how this is done.

Adding the overlay

Since I am denoting a range, the obvious overlay to use is MKCircle, and the code for this is pretty simple.

MKCircle wifiRange = MKCircle.Circle (annotation.Coordinate, 200);  
this.InternetLocationsMap.AddOverlay(wifiRange);

Note: InternetLocationsMaps is my MKMapView.

Im just using arbitrary range of 200 metres here. (Which is generous for a consumer grade WiFi device I know)

MapDelegate

If you look at the Xamarin documentation it will talk about creating a custom annotation, and the path we are going to take here is very similar.

The pertinent code here is:

private class MapDelegate : MKMapViewDelegate  

            public override MKOverlayRenderer OverlayRenderer(MKMapView mapView, IMKOverlay overlay)
            {
                return new WiFiRangeOverlayRenderer (overlay, WifiRange);
            }

            public override MKOverlayView GetViewForOverlay(MKMapView mapView, NSObject overlay)
            {
                return new WifiRangeOverlayView (overlay, WifiRange);
            }

The OverlayRenderer is for iOS 7, the GetViewForOverlay override is for older versions of iOS. If running an iOS 7 device and an OverlayRender method is implemented the GetViewForOverlay logic will not fire.

Just make sure that your map uses the delegate (I do this inside the controllers ViewDidLoad) method:

this.InternetLocationsMap.Delegate = new MapDelegate ();

Overlay view / renderer

I am going to show these two classes together, because in the case of this example their code is basically identical.

internal class WiFiRangeOverlayRenderer : MKOverlayRenderer  
    {
        private readonly WiFiRangeImageHelper _helper;

        public WiFiRangeOverlayRenderer(IMKOverlay overlay, UIImage image) : base(overlay)
        {
            _helper = new WiFiRangeImageHelper (overlay, image);
        }

        public override void DrawMapRect (MKMapRect mapRect, float zoomScale, MonoTouch.CoreGraphics.CGContext context)
        {
            _helper.DrawMapRect (mapRect, context, this.RectForMapRect);
        }
    }

internal class WifiRangeOverlayView : MKOverlayView  
    {
        private readonly WiFiRangeImageHelper _helper;

        public WifiRangeOverlayView (NSObject overlay, UIImage image) : base(overlay)
        {
            _helper = new WiFiRangeImageHelper (overlay, image);
        }

        public override void DrawMapRect (MKMapRect mapRect, float zoomScale, MonoTouch.CoreGraphics.CGContext context)
        {
            _helper.DrawMapRect (mapRect, context, this.RectForMapRect);
        }
    }

All they effectively do is daisy chain the logic into the WiFiRangeImageHelper class which is explained below.

Drawing the image

The helper class I am calling is where all of the work happens. 

internal class WiFiRangeImageHelper  
    {
        private readonly UIImage _wifiRangeImage;
        private readonly MKMapRect _mapBounds;

        public WiFiRangeImageHelper(object overlay, UIImage image)
        {
            _wifiRangeImage = image;
            _mapBounds = ((MKCircle)overlay).BoundingMapRect;
        }

        public void DrawMapRect (MKMapRect mapRect, MonoTouch.CoreGraphics.CGContext context, Func<MKMapRect, RectangleF> calculateDisplayRectangle)
        {
            RectangleF bounds = calculateDisplayRectangle(_mapBounds);
            context.ScaleCTM (1, -1);
            context.TranslateCTM (0, -bounds.Height);
            context.DrawImage (bounds, _wifiRangeImage.CGImage);
        }
    }

There are a few things to note here.

My whole naming / implementation approach was pretty lazy, it is just a proof of concept though, and I'm sure you can do better.

I wasnt able to figure out why the constructors overlay size was different from the one passed into DrawMapRect, but it looked far more correct.

The Func gives an opportunity for the MKOverlayView and MKOverlayRenderer to pass in their logic for converting map based dimensions to a drawable bound on the screen.

If you want an explanation of the logic within DrawMapRect I suggest you take a look at the Xamarin documentation but basic cliff notes are.

  • Correct the image so that its origin is in the top left corner instead of the bottom right (which is the default). For my image this doesnt make a difference as it is a circle radial, but I have included the logic for completeness.
  • Draw the image onto the users screen.

Note: If looking at Objective C examples please note that Xamarin does not use a number of Apple types for drawing. From their documentation - they have replaced CGRect, CGPoint, and CGSize with System.Drawing types.

Resources

I used a combination of online resources to figure this out. The key resource for this was an excellent blog post written by Ray Wenderlich which explains in Objective C how this is done.

I also used these resources for my translation to Xamarin / C#:

  • Xamarin iOS overlay documentation
  • Xamarin RectForMapRect documentation
  • Apples MapKit datatypes

One thing this exercise has taught me though. I really need to learn how to read Objective C code.

item.title: Azure Mobile Services Mapped TableController
item.description:
This blog post details how the Mobile Services ApiController serves up data to the mobile clients in my proof of concept.

By default Azure Mobile Services provides a DomainManager which directly exposes the entity over the wire. Often, particularly for more complex systems you do not want to directly expose
item.dc:creator: Stephen Kennedy
item.content:encoded:
This blog post details how the Mobile Services ApiController serves up data to the mobile clients in my proof of concept.

By default Azure Mobile Services provides a DomainManager which directly exposes the entity over the wire. Often, particularly for more complex systems you do not want to directly expose your underlying entities, but expose contracts crafted specifically for the service. And, in the case of the proof of concept we cannot directly expose all of the entity data as the InternetLocation class contains a DbGeography property that cannot be serialized.

There are two reasons why we want to expose a separate service contract. Firstly, our entity has a member of type DbGeography. This type cannot be serialized in its current format. We expose a contract of type MapLocation in its place which contains the longitude and latitude of the location. Secondly, in many cases you do not want to expose your internal entities directly over the wire. There are many blog posts on the Internet regarding this, but the simple nutshell is that by exposing your internal entities over the wire you are leaking your internal implementation, and you are unable to create contracts specifically to meet your clients needs.

For a refresher on the data contracts we are using see here.

MappedEntityDomainManager

As I stated above, the default template for an Azure Mobile Services TableController exposes entities, however, we want to expose a different service contract. By inheriting from the MappedEntityDomainManager which is briefly described here we are able to internally utilize our persisted entities while exposing service contracts.

Note: As engineers we tend to scour the Internet quite often looking for answers to problems, and as such, blog posts, tend to contain, answers instead of questions. Unfortunately, this is not such a blog post. I've been looking at the recently released Azure Mobile Services (.Net) backend libraries and while I have a working solution, at present this is probably not what the Azure team was after in terms of best practice. Hopefully, if the Azure team can update their documentation / guidance I will come back and update this blog post.

MappedEntityDomainManager uses AutoMapper to map between the domain entities and service contracts.

InternetLocationDomainManager

Arguably, I should have explained this class in the data blog post. However, I decided that it would be clearer what was going on if explained in conjunction with the TableController.

For my implementation I used the sample class as a baseline. While I have implemented the abstract members as per the sample, unfortunately I could not verify that they are actually being called(see testing the mapping).

Entity mappings

I made my AutoMapper mappings part of the WebApiConfig.Register method call. The mappings are as such:

 Mapper.Initialize(cfg =>
            {
                cfg.CreateMap< DbGeography, MapLocation >()
                    .ForMember(dst => dst.Latitude, map => map.MapFrom(s => s.Latitude.Value))
                    .ForMember(dst => dst.Longitude, map => map.MapFrom(s => s.Longitude.Value));

                cfg.CreateMap< InternetLocation, InternetLocationModel >()
                    .ForMember(dst => dst.Location, map => map.MapFrom(s => s.Location));
            });

Since I am only doing a one-way mapping from my domain entity to the service contract I only require one way mappings. One for the InternetLocationModel that I expose, and one for the MapLocation model that is part of the InternetLocationModel contract.

Testing that the mapping works

This bit is weird. It may just have been my development environment (recent rebuild) but I cannot seem to get the debugger to hit a breakpoint on my InternetLocationDomainManager (it will break on my TableController). Through the responses that come back from the service though I have been able to verify that the mapping is occurring. This is both through the mobile applications which have their own custom method, as well as through the webpages that Microsoft provide you to test with. A call to the service with the relative URL of:

tables/InternetLocation?$filter=(hasWifi eq true)

Will return only the Internet locations that have WiFi in the expected JSON format.

The Code

public class InternetLocationDomainManager : MappedEntityDomainManager <InternetLocationModel , InternetLocation >

You will see in this class declaration that there are two generic arguments. The first generic argument is the type that will be exposed over the wire, the second is for the persisted entity type. One thing that I did not mention in my discussion about the proof of concept data types is that InternetLocationModel inherits from ITableData, this is due to the generic where constraint on the first generic type argument. I'm not going to go into too much detail on all of the abstract method overloads as the sample class is pretty easy to follow. But I will showcase two of the methods involved in mapping.

protected override SingleResult <InternetLocationModel > LookupEntity(Expression <Func <InternetLocation , bool >> filter)  
        {
            DataVicContext context = (DataVicContext ) this .Context;

            return SingleResult .Create(context.InternetLocations.Where(filter)
                .Select( Mapper.Map< InternetLocationModel >).AsQueryable());
        }
public override SingleResult <InternetLocationModel > Lookup( string id)  
        {
            var key = GetKey< string>(id);
            InternetLocation location = this .Context.Set<InternetLocation >().Find(key);
            List< InternetLocationModel > result = new List <InternetLocationModel >();

            if (location != null)
            {
                result.Add( Mapper.Map< InternetLocationModel >(location));
            }

            return SingleResult .Create(result.AsQueryable());
        }

These methods are what perform the mapping between the internal entity and the exposed service contract.

InternetLocationController

As we are using a different DomainManager from the standard template the code here is also a bit different. This is the entire class in all of its glory: 

public class InternetLocationController : TableController <InternetLocationModel >  
    {
        private DataVicContext _context;

        protected override void Initialize( HttpControllerContext controllerContext)
        {
            base.Initialize(controllerContext);
            _context = new DataVicContext (Services.Settings.Name);
            this.DomainManager = new InternetLocationDomainManager (_context, Request, Services);
        }

        /// <summary>
        /// Gets all of the locations that have internet available.
        /// </summary>
        /// <returns> Internet locations. </returns>
        public IQueryable <InternetLocationModel > GetLocations()
        {
            return this.Query();
        }

        /// <summary>
        /// Gets all of the internet locations given near a given geography point and within a certain range.
        /// </summary>
        /// <param name="longitude"> Longitude of the location to use as the center of the search.</param>
        /// <param name="latitude"> Latitude of the location to use as the center of the search.</param>
        /// <param name="distance"> Distance in metres to search out from. </param>
        /// <returns> All of the internet locations within the distance from the given point.</returns>
        public IEnumerable <InternetLocationModel > GetLocationsNear( double latitude, double longitude, long distance = 2000)
        {
            try
            {
                 DbGeography geoLocation = GeographyHelper .FromLatitudeLongitude(latitude, longitude);
                var dbLocations = ( from l in _context.InternetLocations
                                   where l.Location.Distance(geoLocation) < distance
                                   select l).ToList();

                return dbLocations.Select( Mapper.Map< InternetLocationModel >);
            }
            catch ( Exception ex)
            {
                Services.Log.Error(ex);
                throw;
            }
        }
    }

The bulk of the logic that performs the actual query against the database is explained in a blog post I found during development. As you can see I have a bit of a hack involved in my custom API method as I am completely bypassing the DomainManager and using the EF context directly. This is because I could not figure out how to perform a distance calculation using the InternetLocationDomainManager. The call to this.Query exposes an InternetLocationModel which is what we return via the service, but, I need to be able to query against the underlying DbGeography class so that I can use the inbuilt spatial data types to query distances.

This is the only method that the mobile applications actually call. They use their inbuilt location services (described in later blog posts) to calculate their location, call the service with their location and then get a set of publicly available Internet locations.

I would gladly accept guidance from the Azure team or community on how to best resolve this.

item.description:
From ten years of greenfield and startup projects to brownfield development, this is what I learnt.

I've been with Readify for around 14 months now. Previous to that I'd largely worked on greenfield projects, be they entirely brand new solutions, or re-writes across a range of clients from startups to
item.dc:creator: Stephen Kennedy
item.content:encoded:
From ten years of greenfield and startup projects to brownfield development, this is what I learnt.

I've been with Readify for around 14 months now. Previous to that I'd largely worked on greenfield projects, be they entirely brand new solutions, or re-writes across a range of clients from startups to large enterprise organizations. Since joining Readify I've pretty much exclusively worked on brownfield projects and it has been interesting to observe (and participate) projects where the consequences of previously made short-term decisions have played out and seeing the true cost of those outcomes.

In my life before Readify I'd generally only involved at the inception and initial creation of a solution. As an engineer I'd known that testing is good, all about SOLID principles, and the many other gems of best practice. I could repeat the rhetoric and attempt to push back when shortcuts were being made, but I'd never really fight it, because like the decision makers I was reporting to I didn't really appreciate the cost of these short-term decisions.

If technical debt is bad why do we let it happen?

Technical debt occurs, and almost every project with a reasonable lifetime has some amount of technical debt. Technical debt often occurs due to short-term decisions being made (be it by the product owner, or the development team), sometimes it occurs because the engineers simply didnt know better, or a legitimate mistake being made by someone.

I feel that it is important to point out that Omniscience is still out of the reach of humankind, and this post isnt necessarily about obtaining perfection, but it is about being productive and competitive through the long-term.

Technical debt, like financial debt isnt evil, it isnt something you want too much of, but something that needs to be managed.

We don't know the true cost of technical debt

But really what does this technical debt cost us? Particularly when we want to feed it back to the decision makers. Unlike financial debt it isnt something that can be accurately be measured back with interest figures in a neat little spreadsheet.

One thing I encourage teams to do when meeting resistance from the decision makers about addressing technical debt is when working on their new features and enhancements to report back on how long it would of taken if the codebase was in reasonable shape.

For example I needed to incorporate server-side caching in a system that was suffering performance problems which in a codebase of reasonable quality should have taken around 3 days, it ended up taking me 3 weeks due to a massively convoluted codebase with no reliable automated testing. So the accrued interest on that technical debt for this piece of work is a productivity cost of around 400%. Obviously different changes to the same component may result in different results but hopefully through averages you will get a clearer picture of cost. Now as the client wants to make far reaching changes to the system as a whole and it affects this component and the decision has been made to re-write it.

Automated tests are your money for a rainy day

We do not have time to write tests. We need new features.

Many startups make this claim. Often they feel pressured by a time to market, particularly if they have no real revenue. More established organisations will also weakly make this claim citing competitors that already have this feature, or concern that they are catching up. Having written a test if you later ignore it in order to check in a change this is as good as that test never existing in the first place as over the ravages of time it can no longer be trusted.

When many people think of automated tests, they only think of it in terms of quality assurance, that the product you are shipping is of a reasonable standard. That is definitely one benefit, and an important one, but there is another benefit often neglected that I would argue is equally as important. A solution with good automated test coverage gives you the ability to make improvements (such as tackling technical debt) without complete fear of change. The better your testing, the less risk that there is associated with change. Some organisations are so scared to change anything at all unless absolutely necessary as the risk is just far too great due to the lack of tests. Tests in a way form an important part of the documentation of your codebase, documentation is valuable, however, it can get out of date, however, a test is always able to verify itself against the codebase.

I would much rather deal with a badly designed system, with poor coding, and riddled with technical debt, but containing a good suite of automated tests, than the other way round. It is actually much easier to correct a poor implementation than large gaps in the knowledge of expected behaviour that automated tests provide.

Also, you need a proper suite of tests. Not just end to end tests, but integration tests, unit tests, and possibly even BDD tests if you are that way inclined.

The longer you leave between initially writing the functionality and writing the automated tests, the greater likelihood that there will be a gap in the automated testing. Test-driven development has its proponents for good reason.

Im not a zealot, you dont need 100% coverage, but you do need enough testing to accurately capture the intent of the system as well as the edge cases.

Why knowing all of the theory often isn't enough

To all of the budding tech start-up entrepreneurs out there - If you are lucky enough to have never worked on a brownfield project before I would highly encourage that you participate in working on an actively developed codebase say 6+ years of age before you start on your new venture.

As I stated at the start of this blog post, I knew the theory, and I followed it (to an extent), but I didnt rally push back hard enough and I probably wasnt as thorough with my automated testing as I should have been. You may be more disciplined than me, but many people (including myself) only really learn by their mistakes, and it is far better to see and understand the outcomes of making these sorts of decisions to really appreciate the why when it comes to testing and managing tech debt.

I have seen a few organisations now that are so crippled by their lack of testing and technical debt that the productivity of their developers is crawling and the end user is becoming more and more aware of the quality and technical debt issues that are occurring. Unless these organisation have strong commercial ties keeping their customer base their competitors eventually start bleeding their market share. That or they end up burning a lot of money and suffer a loss of momentum on a rewrite.

item.title: Finding Locations With Bing Maps on a Server
item.description:
This blog post is supplementary to the Azure Mobile Services Scheduled Jobs blog post. In this blog post I will briefly go over getting a server to query the Bing Maps REST API in order to find geo-location data for a supplied address.

It's Not Just About Code

But, before
item.dc:creator: Stephen Kennedy
item.content:encoded:
This blog post is supplementary to the Azure Mobile Services Scheduled Jobs blog post. In this blog post I will briefly go over getting a server to query the Bing Maps REST API in order to find geo-location data for a supplied address.

It's Not Just About Code

But, before you can being calling the Bing API you need to set up an API key so that Bing can identify who is calling it. In many situations this is a free service, however, there are some cases where Microsoft will charge you to utilize the Bing API. Microsoft have a great little questionnaire that will help you to figure out if there is any cost involved in the use of their API. For my proof of concept since I would be providing this application as a free public consumer mobile application it has no costs associated with it.

There may also be quota restrictions around the usage of the API depending on your level of licensing. Consult the Bing Maps licensing page for more information.

Obtaining a Bing Maps API Key

First up, visit the Bing Maps Portal and sign in with your Microsoft account. Fill in all of the necessary information required to create an account and then go to the Create or view keys link. Fill in a few basic details about your application and then you should have a key. Take this key and then use it when creating requests on the Bing Maps API.

When creating an instance of the BingGeoCoder you supply this API key as its constructor argument. The BingGeoCoder will include this key as part of all geo-location requests. This key correlates to the key querystring parameter in the REST API.

Bing Geocoding Helper

BingGeoCodingHelper is a small Nuget package that I found which acts as a .Net wrapper for Bing's REST API. It is fairly basic, and you will probably want to roll your own for production purposes, but for my proof of concept it was adequate. You can at least use it as a starting point, at least in terms of how to start calling Bing's API. It is open source and present on Github.

Note: If you look at BingGeoCoder's source code you will see that its Geocode method that takes a set of address parameters is hard coded to US. You may need to create your own query. The Rest API location documentation can be found here .

Querying

Here is the call I make through BingGeoCoder in my proof of concept. As I want to persist this information in my database I am converting the result to the DbGeography class, however, you can do whatever you want with the result sent back by Bing Maps.

public DbGeography GetGeography(string address, string suburb, int postCode)  
{
     BingGeocoderResult result = _client.Geocode(String .Format(" {0}, {1} , {2}, Australia", address, suburb, postCode));

     if (result.Confidence == "No results")
     {
         return null;
     }

     return GeographyHelper.FromLatitudeLongitude(double .Parse(result.Latitude), double.Parse(result.Longitude));
}

public static class GeographyHelper  
{
    public static DbGeography FromLatitudeLongitude(double latitude, double longitude)
    {
        return DbGeography.PointFromText(string .Format("POINT( {0} {1} )", longitude, latitude), 4326);
    }
}

By looking at BingGeoCoder's source code I know that if an error occurs, or if it finds no matches then it will return the string 'No results' which means my DbGeography cannot be found. If I do get a response back with some level of confidence then I can use the inbuilt .Net method PointFromText from the DbGeography class to return a database persistable geography location.
